docs.snippet: The Knicks, who have dominated the Celtics for three games, will play Game 4 without their second leading scorer, J.R. Smith, who was suspended for his flagrant foul on Boston’s Jason Terry....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Knicks, who have dominated the Celtics for three games, will play Game 4 without their second leading scorer, J.R. Smith, who was suspended for his flagrant foul on Boston’s Jason Terry.
docs.abstract: NBA suspends New York Knicks shooting guard J R Smith for Game 4 of their first-round playoff series against Boston Celtics after Smith elbowed Celtics guard Jason Terry in the chin, bringing an automatic ejection for a flagrant foul.

headline.seo: Knicks’ J.R. Smith Is Suspended for Game 4 Against Celtics
headline.main: With Flick of His Elbow, Knicks’ Smith Throws Celtics a Lifeline
headline.print_headline: With Flick of His Elbow, Knicks’ Smith Throws Celtics a Lifeline

docs.snippet: A  reporting credit  on April 14 with an article about the current incarnation of the American Basketball Association misspelled the surname of a researcher who contributed. He is Jack Styczynski, not Stycynski....
docs.lead_paragraph: A reporting credit on April 14 with an article about the current incarnation of the American Basketball Association misspelled the surname of a researcher who contributed. He is Jack Styczynski, not Stycynski.

docs.snippet: MILCAREK--Dr. Barry Ivor, left this world suddenly and peacefully at home on April 20, 2013, doing what he loved most, tending to his garden. Dr. Milcarek is leaving behind his devoted wife, Mary McLean, and his parents, Shirley and Ivor Milcarek;...
docs.lead_paragraph: MILCAREK--Dr. Barry Ivor, left this world suddenly and peacefully at home on April 20, 2013, doing what he loved most, tending to his garden. Dr. Milcarek is leaving behind his devoted wife, Mary McLean, and his parents, Shirley and Ivor Milcarek; Barry also leaves behind his daughter, Heather (Michael Miller) and son Rory, both of whom he loved more than any words can express. He will be missed by his sister, Doreen Milcarek (Kenneth Burke), brother Kevin, niece Katharine and nephew Neil. Barry enjoyed his work and colleagues at the University of Delaware where he served as Senior Biostatistician in the College of Heath Sciences. Barry was an avid sports fan - he loved college basketball and football, but had a special love for youth hockey, where he once coached children, including his beloved son Rory. A private service is being planned. In lieu of flowers, if you would like to make a donation in Barry's memory, please give to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, P.O. Box 1000, Memphis, TN 38148, Tribute Account #

docs.snippet: GALLANTZ--George G., passed away on April 24, 2013, the day after his 100th birthday. All of us at Proskauer Rose LLP mourn his passing. George will be remembered as a "lawyer's lawyer," known for his outstanding legal skills, wealth of experience...
docs.lead_paragraph: GALLANTZ--George G., passed away on April 24, 2013, the day after his 100th birthday. All of us at Proskauer Rose LLP mourn his passing. George will be remembered as a "lawyer's lawyer," known for his outstanding legal skills, wealth of experience and insight and special touch for teaching younger lawyers. A Proskauer partner since 1963, George mentored an extraordinary group of lawyers who have had an enduring impact both on our Firm, as well as on the legal and sports world - including Michael Cardozo, New York City's Corporation Counsel; David Stern, Commissioner of the National Basketball Association and Gary Bettman, Commissioner of the National Hockey League. The founding father of Proskauer's Sports Law Practice, George leaves behind a legacy of commitment, brilliance, friendship and uncompromising integrity. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. He will be missed by all who knew him - family, friends, colleagues and clients alike. Joseph M. Leccese Chairman Proskauer Rose LLP

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLANTZ, GEORGE G.

docs.snippet: We know that stretching before exercise tends to be counterproductive because, in loosening muscles, it also temporarily weakens them. But whether you should stretch at other times — after exercise, for instance, or first thin...
docs.lead_paragraph: We know that stretching before exercise tends to be counterproductive because, in loosening muscles, it also temporarily weakens them. But whether you should stretch at other times — after exercise, for instance, or first thing in the morning or just before bed — is murkier, in part because studies of stretching have not been standardized. Some have had young, healthy volunteers stretch for 20 minutes or more; others for 5 minutes or less. Still others have used older, stiffer volunteers or people with existing injuries. Not surprisingly, the results have been inconsistent. Even within the same study, people respond quite differently to stretching, with some showing increased flexibility and others not.
